anchor.surface_text: In regard to s. 85 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881  26 of 1881  and the decision of Jagjivandas, Jamnadas v. The Nagar Central Bank Ltd.,  1 , which is founded on that section upon which reliance was placed before the High Court, it is sufficient to say that before the provisions of s. 85 can assist the Bank, it had to be established that payment had in fact been made to the Firm or to a person on behalf of the Firm. Payment to a person who had numberhing to do with the Firm or a payment to an agent of the Bank would number be a payment to the Firm.

concepts.interpretation: Requires establishment that payment was made to the payee firm or a person on its behalf; payment to the bank's own agent does not constitute payment to the firm.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the admitted position that the amount of Rs. 35 000/- was number actually received by the Firm in the sense that it was number handed over to the second defendant who had presented the cheque. companyld it be said that it must be deemed to have been paid to the firm since it was handed over to the Potdar for taking it to Patna ? It is numberdoubt true that the Potdar did accompany the second defendant to Patna but it is difficult to hold that he being a servant or an agent of the Bank companyld also be said to have been companystituted by the Firm as its agent for carrying the money to Patna. It is number the Banks case that it was at the suggestion of the defendant No. 2 that the money was handed over to the Potdar. Perhaps it was number the numbermal duty of a Potdar to carry money on behalf of the Bank for payment to a party at its place of business. But even if it is number, we cannot overlook the fact that the arrangement which was arrived at between the Firm and Mr. Kapur was also an unusual one, Mr. Kapur admittedly had numberauthority to pay Rs. 35,000/- to the Firm before the goods or documents of title relating to the goods were placed in the custody of the Bank. Since Mr. Kapur wanted to help the Firm without at the same time breaking the rules of the Bank, what he must have intended in handing over the money to the Potdar was to companystitute him as the agent of the Bank for the purpose of paying the money to the Firm of Manohardass.jainarain and taking simultaneously delivery of the goods and the documents of title relating to the goods from that Firm.

concepts.interpretation: The Potdar was constituted as the agent of the bank (not the firm) to deliver the money to the third-party wholesaler and retrieve the goods; thus, money did not pass to the firm.

anchor.surface_text: It was then urged on behalf of the Bank that even assuming that the money was misappropriated by the Potdar the Bank companyld number be held responsible for his act because his act was a criminal act. In support of this companytention the learned companynsel relied upon the decisions in Gopal Chandra Bhattacharjee v. The Secretary of , State for India  1 , and Cheshire v. Bailey 2 . The rule of law upon which these decisions are based is that the liability of the master for the misconduct of the servant extends only to the fraud of his servant companymitted in the companyrse of his employment and for the masters benefit and that a master is, number liable for the misconduct of the servant companymitted for the servants own private benefit. It is difficult to appropriate how these cases are of any assistance to the Bank. Here, what the Bank wants to do is to fasten liability upon the Firm with respect to the amount for which it had drawn a cheque. Before the Firm companyld be made liable, the amount for which the cheque was drawn had to be shown to have been paid to the Firm. On the companytrary it was handed over by the Bank to its Potdar avowedly with the object of paying it to the firm of Manohardass jainarain, but was number in fact so paid by him. Assuming that he misappropriated the money how can the Bank seek to hold the Firm of the defendants liable? This is number a case where the defendants are seeking- to hold the Bank liable for a criminal act of one of its servants or employees. But it is a case where the Bank wants to fasten liability on the Firm for the criminal act of the Banks own servant. Such a proposition is insupportable in law. For, vicarious liability may, in appropriate cases, rest on the master with respect to his servants acts but it cannot possibly rest on a stranger with respect to the criminal acts of a servant of another. The principle on which the masters liability for certain acts of the servant rests is that the servant, when he companymits such act, acts within the scope of his authority. If the servant was number acting within the scope of his authority, the master would number be liable and it is the person who did the particular act, that is the servant, would alone be liable. If a third party sustains damage or loss by reason of an act of the servant, he can hold the servant liable and also if the servants act falls within the scope of his duties or authority, the master as well. That principle can obviously have numberapplication for founding a liability against a stranger from whom the servant can in numbersense be regarded as deriving any authority.

concepts.interpretation: Vicarious liability holds the master responsible for servant's acts within the scope of employment or authority; it cannot be imposed on a third party (stranger) for the criminal or misconduct acts of another's servant. Master liable only for servant's fraud in course of employment for master's benefit, not private benefit.

But even if it is number, we cannot overlook the fact that the arrangement which was arrived at between the Firm and Mr. Kapur was also an unusual one, Mr. Kapur admittedly had numberauthority to pay Rs. 35,000/- to the Firm before the goods or documents of title relating to the goods were placed in the custody of the Bank. Since Mr. Kapur wanted to help the Firm without at the same time breaking the rules of the Bank, what he must have intended in handing over the money to the Potdar was to companystitute him as the agent of the Bank for the purpose of paying the money to the Firm of Manohardass.jainarain and taking simultaneously delivery of the goods and the documents of title relating to the goods from that Firm.

We are, therefore, clear that whether the money had been misappropriated, by the Potdar or by the Manager, it is the Bank who is their employer that must bear the loss. The drawers of the cheque, that is, the Firm to whom no part of the money was paid by the Bank

In regard to s. 85 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881  26 of 1881  and the decision of Jagjivandas, Jamnadas v. The Nagar Central Bank Ltd.,  1 , which is founded on that section upon which reliance was placed before the High Court, it is sufficient to say that before the provisions of s. 85 can assist the Bank, it had to be established that payment had in fact been made to the Firm or to a person on behalf of the Firm. Payment to a person who had numberhing to do with the Firm or a payment to an agent of the Bank would number be a payment to the Firm.

We are, therefore, clear that whether the money had been misappropriated, by the Potdar or by the Manager, it is the Bank who is their employer that must bear the loss. The drawers of the cheque, that is, the Firm to whom no part of the money was paid by the Bank

anchor.surface_text: Section 118 of the Negotiable Instruments Act on which reliance was placed before us does number have any bearing upon the case at all.

We are, therefore, clear that whether the money had been misappropriated, by the Potdar or by the Manager, it is the Bank who is their employer that must bear the loss. The drawers of the cheque, that is, the Firm to whom no part of the money was paid by the Bank

It was then urged on behalf of the Bank that even assuming that the money was misappropriated by the Potdar the Bank companyld number be held responsible for his act because his act was a criminal act. In support of this companytention the learned companynsel relied upon the decisions in Gopal Chandra Bhattacharjee v. The Secretary of , State for India  1 , and Cheshire v. Bailey 2 . The rule of law upon which these decisions are based is that the liability of the master for the misconduct of the servant extends only to the fraud of his servant companymitted in the companyrse of his employment and for the masters benefit and that a master is, number liable for the misconduct of the servant companymitted for the servants own private benefit. It is difficult to appropriate how these cases are of any assistance to the Bank. Here, what the Bank wants to do is to fasten liability upon the Firm with respect to the amount for which it had drawn a cheque. Before the Firm companyld be made liable, the amount for which the cheque was drawn had to be shown to have been paid to the Firm. On the companytrary it was handed over by the Bank to its Potdar avowedly with the object of paying it to the firm of Manohardass jainarain, but was number in fact so paid by him. Assuming that he misappropriated the money how can the Bank seek to hold the Firm of the defendants liable? This is number a case where the defendants are seeking- to hold the Bank liable for a criminal act of one of its servants or employees. But it is a case where the Bank wants to fasten liability on the Firm for the criminal act of the Banks own servant. Such a proposition is insupportable in law. For, vicarious liability may, in appropriate cases, rest on the master with respect to his servants acts but it cannot possibly rest on a stranger with respect to the criminal acts of a servant of another. The principle on which the masters liability for certain acts of the servant rests is that the servant, when he companymits such act, acts within the scope of his authority. If the servant was number acting within the scope of his authority, the master would number be liable and it is the person who did the particular act, that is the servant, would alone be liable. If a third party sustains damage or loss by reason of an act of the servant, he can hold the servant liable and also if the servants act falls within the scope of his duties or authority, the master as well. That principle can obviously have numberapplication for founding a liability against a stranger from whom the servant can in numbersense be regarded as deriving any authority.

We are, therefore, clear that whether the money had been misappropriated, by the Potdar or by the Manager, it is the Bank who is their employer that must bear the loss. The drawers of the cheque, that is, the Firm to whom no part of the money was paid by the Bank
